channel.title: Learn to Code on Pandaqi Tutorials
channel.description: Recent content in Learn to Code on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: You want to learn how to program. Smart! Programming is a job in high demand, with a high salary and many opportunities.

item.title: Solving Puzzles
item.description: You have something you want to do. A problem to solve—or a puzzle, that sounds more fun. Say you’re making a game.

item.title: Data Types
item.description: Data types will always be your first step into any programming language—or any problem. That’s not surprising: you already know that coding is just “changing data”.

item.title: Variables
item.description: Alright, you can now define data (bool, number, string) and do some calculations. But once you have your result, you want to store it somewhere.

item.title: Variables II: Naming
item.description: Previous chapter introduced you to the wonderful world of giving names to everything. But can you use any name for your variable?

item.title: Conditionals I
item.description: What you’ve learned so far is already very powerful. Hopefully you’ve played around with the examples, tried writing your own little programs.

item.title: Conditionals II
item.description: Last chapter introduced turning everything into a bool. And then using that to determine if we want to execute a group of code or not.

item.title: Numbers
item.description: This chapter is probably most fun if we use an example throughout. (Otherwise, numbers easily become abstract and, well, boring.

item.title: Strings
item.description: String transformations are more fun and specific than the ones for numbers. But they are also more varied, with a huge number of possible things you might want to do.

item.title: Comments & Space
item.description: Human language uses a lot of space. We put a space between every word! We put space around text in a book.

item.title: Loops I
item.description: A crucial principle in programming is “DRY”: Don’t Repeat Yourself. That’s the beauty of a computer: it doesn’t mind executing the same task 1000 times for you.

item.title: Loops II
item.description: Last chapter introduced you to loops. It also teased a different way to play with how many (or which) iterations are executed.

item.title: Bags I
item.description: Loops really start to shine when you combine it with repeated data: a bag full of values. They’re like twins.

item.title: Bags II
item.description: Last chapter teased the idea of naming the elements inside your bag. Like we give names to things in the real world.

item.title: Bags III
item.description: What can we do so far? We can define a bag and get what’s inside. But that’s not all you can do with a bag.

item.title: Machines I
item.description: Congratulations! You’ve arrived at the final boss of programming. Not necessarily because it’s hard, but because it’s the most important and powerful tool.

item.title: Machines II
item.description: You’ve learned how to define (or “create”) a machine and how to tell it to do something. But just like our coffee machine needs beans to create coffee, most machines you write will need some input.

item.title: Machines III
item.description: As you know by now, I am fond of recreating functionality yourself. Even if a language supports something (with an easy keyword), I think it’s a great exercise to try and code it yourself.

item.title: Machines IV
item.description: This is the last chapter with exercises / examples for machines. As you noticed, machines get more chapters than any other topic!

item.title: Debugging
item.description: Here’s a secret. As a programmer, you actually don’t spend most of your time programming. Instead, most of the time you are reading or fixing code in a process called debugging.

item.title: Data Manipulation I
item.description: In these two chapters, I want to give a few slightly more “advanced” ways for manipulating data. Again, every programming language will have these.

item.title: Data Manipulation II
item.description: In the Strings chapter, I promised some more “bag-like” operations to do on strings. They can be extremely important or not important at all, depending on your project.

item.title: Where to go now?
item.description: Well done! You’ve read and worked through the whole course. The hard part is over. Why? Because any language you’ll use in the future will have the things I mentioned.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: This concludes the course about learning to code. Hopefully, I was able to ignite a spark. That’s why I learned to code, so long ago.
